'''Richard Louis Trumka''' (born July 24, 1949)<ref name="WhosWho">''Who's Who in America.'' 62nd ed. New Providence, N.J.: Marquis Who's Who, 2007. ISBN 0083797011</ref> is an [[organized labor]] leader and [[communist]] in the [[United States]]. He was elected President of the [[AFL-CIO]] on September 16, 2009, at the [[National trade union center|labor federation]]'s convention in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]].<ref name="SweeneyRetire">[http://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/16/business/16labor.html Greenhouse, Steven. "Promising a New Day, Again."] ''New York Times.'' September 15, 2009; [http://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/13/us/13labor.html Greenhouse, Steven. "Labor Leader Is Stepping Down Both Proud and Frustrated."] ''New York Times.'' September 12, 2009.</ref> He served as the Secretary-Treasurer of the AFL-CIO, from 1995 to 2009, and prior to that was President of the [[United Mine Workers]] from 1982 to December 22, 1995.
+
'''Richard Louis Trumka''' (born July 24, 1949)<ref name="WhosWho">''Who's Who in America.'' 62nd ed. New Providence, N.J.: Marquis Who's Who, 2007. ISBN 0083797011</ref> is an [[organized labor]] leader in the [[United States]]. He was elected President of the [[AFL-CIO]] on September 16, 2009, at the [[National trade union center|labor federation]]'s convention in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]].<ref name="SweeneyRetire">[http://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/16/business/16labor.html Greenhouse, Steven. "Promising a New Day, Again."] ''New York Times.'' September 15, 2009; [http://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/13/us/13labor.html Greenhouse, Steven. "Labor Leader Is Stepping Down Both Proud and Frustrated."] ''New York Times.'' September 12, 2009.</ref> He served as the Secretary-Treasurer of the AFL-CIO, from 1995 to 2009, and prior to that was President of the [[United Mine Workers]] from 1982 to December 22, 1995.
